### Problem

Connect to a remote machine over ssh, try to open two split buffers and then scroll on one buffer. The screen containing the other buffer will get corrupted.
![demo](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/36561860/f7c56de7-da3e-43b9-8349-be7bd6df3a49)


### Steps to reproduce

- ssh to a remote machine (tested with both `gnome-terminal` and `alacritty`).
- nvim -u NORC .
- Open two new buffers vertically.
- Edit the "old" buffer.
- The "new" buffer will be corrupted.
**Note:** This issue happen intermittenly. I can reliably reproduce it by opening a `yaml` file first before creating another buffer. I also made sure that correct `terminfo` is already installed (xterm256-color for gnome-terminal and alacritty for alacritty).

### Expected behavior

In a remote machine, scrolling should not corrupted vertical buffers.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.10.0-dev-2150+ge68decab0

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, vim 8.2.2121

### Operating system/version

Ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS (Remote machine); ArchLinux (host)

### Terminal name/version

gnome-terminal (Gnome 45)

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

Install in the remote machine through github release tarball.

Ok, just a headsup on my litle investigation on this.

DevPod seems to be the "culprit" here. What happens is, when you run "devpod up" the container is created and you are told to do "ssh yourworkscape.devpod". It turns out DevPod change your ~/.ssh/config and this ssh command is actualy a ProxyCommand in your ~/.ssh/config like this: "ProxyCommand devpod ssh --stdio --context default --user dev yourworkspace".

The thing is, no matter what I change inside the container, accessing it with this command always break Neovim/Astronvim UI.

So, at the end. I came with two workaround for this:
1. wrap your session with Tmux or Screen and run neovim (after you enter the container with ssh as being told by devpod)
2. access your container with docker ie: docker container exec -it containername bash, and run neovim

Both approach works perfectly, but its still a bit annoying :)

I spent the past couple of hours trying to get this to work as it was driving me crazy. After trying @marcelomendes first workaround; running tmux inside the container then opening neovim. That worked for me.

So I took a look at the output of env, and saw that TERM was set to "screen". I had tried changing the TERM variable to xterm or alacritty (I did install the terminal info as well with no luck) or xterm-256color with no luck.

So I added the following to the beginning .ssh/config, this will match any containers created by devpod
```
Host *.devpod
  ForwardAgent yes
  LogLevel error
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  UserKnownHostsFile /dev/null
  User vscode
  SetEnv TERM=screen

```

And now neovim is working as expected. I'm not sure what the ProxyCommand that devpod uses does but it looks like the screen terminal type is simple enough that it works.
